text: Fourth, Arctic stakeholders are experienced at integrating collaborative scientific and health policy development across disciplines, cultures and borders (23) . Networks are in place that coordinate different aspects of Arctic health including environmental monitoring, animal and human disease surveillance and reporting (9) . Fifth, there is recognition of the need for an operational, multidisciplinary and holistic model for assessing and responding to all health risks (18) . Finally, there is a track record of policy makers receptive to and influenced by knowledge from diverse scientific and traditional disciplines. For example, scientific data and Indigenous traditional knowledge have resulted in evidence-based policy development in the United States, Canada and Nordic countries on research agendas, interpreting data and local community policy formulation (24) .
